thread.section_title: Latest business and finance news from New Zealand and the world's key markets - Yahoo New Zealand Finance
thread.title: $A hits new lows as Chinese stocks plunge
thread.title_full: $A hits new lows as Chinese stocks plunge

title: $A hits new lows as Chinese stocks plunge
text:
Thu, Jul 9, 2015, 12:36 AM NZST - New Zealand Markets open in 9 hrs 24 mins $A hits new lows as Chinese stocks plunge AAP – 4 hours ago Print 
The Australian dollar is taking a battering from another day of steep falls on the Chinese stock market. 
At 1700 AEST on Wednesday, the local unit was trading at 73.84 US cents, down from 74.85 cents on Tuesday. 
During the day it fell to a new six year low of 73.72 US cents and dropped below 90 Japanese yen for the first time in over a year. 
It also fell to a six year low against the British pound. 
Thinkforex senior market analyst Matt Simpson said the plunging Chinese market is a much greater focus for local investors than a possible exit by Greece from the euro zone. 
The Shanghai share market has fallen around 30 per cent in the past three weeks after a staggering 120 per cent rally over the previous eight months. 
"The Australian dollar had already suffered a turbulent session overnight as concerns about a Grexit regained momentum," Mr Simpson said. 
"The China stock market bubble however clearly has investors more concerned for the domestic markets judging by the negative reaction from Australia dollar crosses." 
Mr Simpson said it appears that intervention to limit the extent of the falls in Chinese shares haven't seemed to have worked. 
"To see those same markets gap down lower is a very worrying sign for investors across the globe and could indeed just be the beginning of something far more sinister," he said. 
The minutes of the US Federal Reserve's most recent policy meeting will be released early on Thursday morning, Australian time, which may take some of the focus away from China and Greece. 
After that, Australian jobs figures will be released which are expected to show that the unemployment rate rose to 6.1 per cent in June from six per cent the month before. 
At 1700 AEST, the Australian dollar was at 89.89 Japanese yen, down from Wednesday's close of 91.83 yen, and at 67.04 euro cents, down from 67.86 euro cents. 
Meanwhile, the Australian bond market is stronger as traders, concerned about the falling Chinese stock market, move into safe haven assets. 
Westpac senior market strategist Damien McColough said China is much more of a concern to Australian markets and the global economy and that has sparked a rally in the bond market. 
"We've now got futures prices pushing the upper end of the recent trading range, resistance levels have held but I wouldn't expect it to hold for much longer," he said. 
"I think there's probably some further gains to be made in overnight trade." 
At 1630 AEST on Wednesday, the September 2015 10-year bond futures contract was trading at 97.210 (implying a yield of 2.790 per cent), up from 97.050 (2.950 per cent) on Tuesday. 
The September 2015 three-year bond futures contract was at 98.160 (1.840 per cent), up from 98.050 (1.950 per cent). @YahooNZBusiness on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Webjet on track to lift full year earnings AAP
